newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo precious metals mixed, palladium lower.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo precious metals mixed, palladium lower.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo precious metal futures ended mixed on Friday, with palladium sharply lower on profit taking amid expectations that Japan-Russia platinum group metal supply talks may soon resume, traders said.
Palladium futures ranged from six yen to 19 yen per gram lower, with benchmark December ending down 18 at 547 yen.
Gold futures were mostly lower, except for April which was up two yen. Benchmark December was down two at 1,361 yen.
"Views are emerging in the market that the upside in palladium will be limited due to expectations that the Japan-Russia talks will resume soon," one senior dealer said.
A Russian trade official in Tokyo said on Friday that he expected Japan-Russia talks on 1997 platinum group metal supplies would be held sometime in March.
Traders said that palladium futures dipped early and then extended those losses on trade house selling.
Spot gold was quoted at $341.70/342.20 per ounce at 0746 GMT, against $340.75/341.25 at New York"s Thursday close.
Spot gold was firmer during Asian hours, led by buying from overseas investors, but resistance was seen at $344.00.
In the gold futures market, individual investors were seen buying early in the day and taking profits later, traders said.
Most silver futures ended sharply higher, buoyed by strong bullion prices, while platinum futures received a boost from active short covering, traders said.
Most-active December silver futures rose the daily limit of 7.0 yen to 207.2 yen per 10 grams.

Benchmark December platinum futures rose 10 yen to 1,442 yen per gram. "Platinum"s rise was led by silver"s strength and recent gains in palladium. Upside potential could be limited as the platinum market lacks any fresh factors," one trader said.
In spot platinum, overseas selling was met by Japanese buying, he said. --Tokyo Commodity Desk +81-3-3432-7431
